entry.title: Mehr als nur Technologie: Wie menschzentrierte KI Akzeptanz und Mehrwert schafft
entry.content:
Dieser Artikel erscheint demnächst leicht angepasst im Buch der Corporate Learning Community, Link darauf folgt. 

Als jemand, der sich seit vielen Jahren mit Lernen in Organisationen, Change Management und Technologietransformation beschäftigt, war für mich schnell klar: Die Einführung generativer KI ist weit mehr als ein IT-Projekt. Es geht um Menschen, um Akzeptanz, um Wandel, um neue Formen des Lernens.

Ich bin schon lange Teil von Communities – sei es durch den Austausch auf BarCamps, durch Gespräche im Podcast oder durch Formate wie dem CLC Promptathon 2024, den ich mit Begeisterung mit organisiert habe. Gerade dieser Promptathon war für mich ein Aha-Erlebnis: In einem hybriden Setting haben wir gemeinsam ausprobiert, wie uns generative KI konkret im Arbeitsalltag unterstützen kann. Es war ein echter Peer-Learning-Prozess – offen, co-kreativ, experimentell mit einer sehr positiven Stimmung im Raum. Genau dieses erlebnisorientierte Lernen, halte ich für entscheidend, wenn wir von KI-Adoption sprechen. Denn KI versteht man nur, wenn man es nutzt.

Lernen entsteht durch Austausch, durch Reflexion, durch das gemeinsame Machen. Durch das gemeinsame Machen entsteht eine Energie, die nie in formellen Belehrungen durch Experten entsteht. Und das gilt auch besonders für KI. Nur wer selbst ausprobiert, wer mit anderen Erfahrungen teilt und gemeinsam Lösungen entwickelt, kann das volle Potenzial heben – für sich persönlich und für die Organisation.

Diese Erfahrungen haben mich in meiner Überzeugung bestärkt, dass die menschzentrierte Gestaltung von KI-Initiativen kein „Nice-to-have“ ist, sondern ein zentraler Erfolgsfaktor. In diesem Artikel möchte ich deshalb meine Perspektive auf die vier entscheidenden Faktoren für erfolgreiche KI-Adoption teilen – mit einem besonderen Fokus auf den Menschen im Zentrum der Veränderung. 

Die Herausforderung der generativen Künstlichen Intelligenz 

Generative KI entwickelt sich mit einer krassen Geschwindigkeit und verändert die Art, wie wir arbeiten, lernen und kommunizieren. Doch während Unternehmen immer mehr in KI-Technologie investieren, bleibt der erhoffte Produktivitätsschub oft aus. Viele reden auch davon, dass wir speziell in Deutschland einen KI-Kompetenz Gap haben. Und neben dieser Kompetenz-Lücke gibt es zudem die Pilot-Falle:  Unternehmen führen zwar oft erfolgreiche Einzelprojekte durch als Piloten, schaffen aber nicht den Sprung zur unternehmensweiten Skalierung.

Die Herausforderung liegt meines Erachtens nicht primär in der Implementierung der Technologie, sondern in der Akzeptanz und effektiven Nutzung durch die Menschen in der Organisation.  

Unternehmen, die KI-Projekte rein technisch betrachten, scheitern häufig an mangelnder Nutzung und Akzeptanz. Diese Nutzung und Akzeptanz wird auch Adoption benannt. Der Schlüssel dazu liegt meiner Ansicht nach in einem integrierten, menschenzentrierten Ansatz, der folgende vier Komponenten umfasst:

  1. Human-Centered Design Mindset & Practices
  2. Technical Support & Consulting
  3. Organizational Change Management
  4. Learning and Enablement (AI Upskilling)

Weiterbildung und Lernen wie es in der Corporate Learning Community praktiziert wird, ist hier einer der wesentlichen Elemente. Daneben ist eine fundierte Strategie notwendig mit klarer Zielsetzung und strukturiertem Vorgehen, Blick auf die technologische Plattform und Architektur, Nutzung hochwertiger Daten.  Je nach Kontext ist zudem die Berücksichtigung von Governance, Ethik und Regulierung – auch „verantwortungsvolle KI“ genannt eminent wichtig.

Die vier Bereiche und Faktoren der AI Adoption

Im Artikel möchte ich mich jedoch dem Thema Adoption, Nutzung & Akzeptanz widmen. Was machen diese vier Faktoren des integrierten, menschenzentrierten Ansatz aus?

 

Abb.1: Die vier Bereiche der AI Adoption

Komponente 1: Human-zentriertes Design - Mindset & Praktiken

Im Kontext von KI bedeutet dies, die Bedürfnisse der Nutzenden in den Mittelpunkt zu stellen und von dort aus zu denken. Für die Entwicklung einer KI-Strategie ist dabei entscheidend, aus der Vielzahl möglicher Anwendungsfälle diejenigen zu identifizieren und zu priorisieren, die einen echten Mehrwert bieten. Bewährte Design-Thinking-Kriterien bieten hierfür einen strukturierten Rahmen:

  • Desirability: Können konkrete Probleme durch KI gelöst werden wo auch Bedarf besteht?
  • Feasibility: Ist eine technische Umsetzung möglich oder ist die Umsetzung nicht unnötig komplex?
  • Viability: Kann das Unternehmen von der Lösung profitieren - gibt es einen Mehrwert?

Für die Auswahl geeigneter KI-Szenarien haben sich Formate wie Business AI Exploration & Discovery Workshops oder Business AI Design Workshops bewährt. Diese Methoden ermöglichen es, echte Nutzerbedürfnisse interdisziplinär zu identifizieren und passende Lösungsansätze zu entwickeln.

Ob Design Thinking, Co-Creation, iteratives Prototyping, agiles Coaching oder andere Methoden – entscheidend ist, dass die Nutzenden im Zentrum steht und Lösungen aus seiner Perspektive gedacht werden. Die Bearbeitung realer Probleme mit echten Nutzerdaten legt den Grundstein für die spätere Akzeptanz und erfolgreiche Implementierung generativer KI. Neben der Nutzung von Wissen gibt es mehr Commitment und Motivation durch Einbindung – sei es auch nur von Vertretern der Nutzer. Sehr nützlich ist hierbei der kostenfreie Methoden Toolkit des SAP Apphaus mit dedizierten KI Workshop Templates. 

Zur Humanzentrierung gehört für mich zudem auch der incl. Reflektion der ethischen Nutzung von KI - mehr dazu im verlinkten Podcast.  

Komponente 2: Technischer Support

Ich finde den Dreiklang nach der SAP KI Strategie sehr schlüssig:

  • Chatbots & conversational Interfaces ob SAP Joule, ChatGPT, Gemini oder Claude als Interface für die KI-gestützte Arbeit
  • In bestehende Software integrierte KI – sei es der MS Co-Pilot bei Microsoft oder verschiedene eingebettete Use Cases in SAP Unternehmenssoftware wie z.B. bei SAP SuccessFactors oder SAP S/4HANA.
  • Das Entwickeln eigener Anwendungen und besonders Agenten zur Optimierung und Automatisierung von Arbeit oder ganz neuer Anwendungen.  

Neben der eigentlichen KI Software, sollte auch die KI Einführung technisch unterstützt werden. Hilfreich dabei sind z.B. Tools für Prozessmanagement, -analyse und -mining, für Zusammenarbeit und Kommunikation wie Enterprise Social Networks mit Wikis, Foren etc., Digital Adoption Plattformen wie WalkMe zu Guidance,  Monitoring & Automatisierung der Nutzererfahrung sowie Tools für Umfragen zur Messung der qualitativen Akzeptanz. SAP fasst diese Digitalsierung von Software Einführung und Betrieb auch unter dem Modell der Digital Toolchain zusammen.

Wichtig ist hier ein Punkt: Einführung von KI sollte nicht (nur) mit alten Tools und Ansätzen gemacht werden wie Powerpoint, Excel oder E-Mail. Hier sollte man auch immer darauf achten, bessere Tools und Ansätze oder sogar KI selbst zu nutzen.   

Komponente 3: Organizational Change Management

Jenseits der individuellen Perspektive bedeutet KI-Adoption stets auch organisatorischer Wandel. Die Erfahrung zeigt: Selbst technisch exzellente KI-Lösungen scheitern, wenn der Veränderungsprozess nicht systematisch gestaltet und begleitet wird. 

Für erfolgreiche Veränderungsprozesse sind verschiedene Faktoren relevant:

  1. Klarheit, Transparenz und Mehrwert: Die Vorteile der neuen Technologie müssen für Organisationen, Teams und einzelne Rollen klar kommuniziert werden. Mitarbeitende müssen verstehen, wie die Technologie ihre Arbeit effizienter und besser macht. Oft werden Vorteile nur High Level auf Management Ebene in Zahlen & high-level KPIs formuliert, was zu abstrakt ist und niemanden abholt.
  2. Vertrauen und Benutzerfreundlichkeit: Das Design aus Nutzerperspektive und der einfache Zugang der KI-Anwendungen sind entscheidend. Vertrauen in die Tools gewinnt zunehmend an Bedeutung. Besonders bei KI sind vertrauensfördernde Maßnahmen wie Transparenz der Modelle, Klärung was mit individuellen Daten geschieht oder Überprüfung auf möglichen Bias wichtig.
  3. Datengestützte Veränderungsbegleitung: Für eine erfolgreiche Transformation empfiehlt sich ein datengestützter Ansatz. Bewährt haben sich fünf Veränderungsdimensionen aus Nutzersicht: Awareness, Acceptance, Enablement, Empowerment und Commitment. Durch regelmäßiges Pulsfühlen dieser Dimensionen entlang der KI Einführung kann der Fortschritt der KI-Adoption gemessen und bei Bedarf nachgesteuert werden. Bei SAP nennen wir das beispielsweise Deep-Transformation-Insights. Die technische Umsetzung davon erfolgt dabei mit Tools für Prozessanalyse und -modellierung sowie systematischen Befragungen. Dies ermöglicht ein präzises Bild des Veränderungsfortschritts und gezielte Maßnahmen bei Akzeptanzproblemen.

Komponente 4: Learning and Enablement   

Eine der großen KI-Investitionen sind derzeit Umschulungen bzw. Weiterbildungen (auch gerne Upskilling genannt). Neben allgemeinem Verständnis und Kenntnissen verschiedener Tools wird oft die Kompetenz des Prompt Engineerings hervorgehoben. Ich würde das weiter fassen und es als Handling von KI Tools wie Chatbots im eigenen Arbeitskontext sehen - oft wird dies auch als AI Literacy bezeichnet.

Darüber hinaus kann es hilfreich sein, fortgeschrittene Techniken zu erlernen im Prompten, das Entwickeln von Assistenten oder Agenten. Menschliche Sprache ersetzt Programmiersprache, und mit generativer KI wird Low- oder No-Code-Entwicklung Realität. Letzteres wird auch gerne Vibe-Coding gennannt.

Neben dem Erlernen und Verständnis von Grundlagen geht es um den Einsatz generativer KI in der jeweiligen täglichen Arbeit. Für wichtige Zielgruppen wie Softwareentwicklung, F&E, Kundenservice, Marketing oder IT werden oft spezielle interne Akademien eingerichtet.

Für den SAP Kontext haben wir im Blog SAP AI Training und SAP AI Skills Self-Assessment relevante KI Lernangebote ausgewählt.

Wie schon erwähnt versteht man KI vor allem, indem man es nutzt. Hierfür eignen sich meiner Meinung nach besonders Ansätze aus dem Peer-Learning. Mögliche Methoden umfassen Workshops oder Hackathons, auch Promtathons genannt, Lernen in Gruppen, Communities oder Mentoring.

Jeder Job hat Aufgaben, bei denen generative KI helfen kann, wie die schnellere oder bessere Recherche, Inhaltserstellung einschließlich Zusammenfassung oder Übersetzung, Datenverarbeitung und -analyse, Softwareentwicklung und etliches mehr.

Eine Möglichkeit des Peer Learning ist das der Lerngruppen oder Lernzirkel. Das LernOS-Framework, ein Rahmenwerk für lebenslanges Lernen mit vielen openSource Lern-Leitfäden beinhaltet beispielsweise einen KI-Lernleitfaden. Dieser Leitfaden strukturiert eine selbstgesteuerte Lernreise kleiner Gruppen mit fachlichem Input und Übungen rund um generative KI. Dies ermöglicht das Lernen am Arbeitsplatz, einschließlich der Analyse und Bearbeitung individueller Anwendungsfälle, und kann einfach und sogar relativ kostenneutral realisiert werden, beispielsweise im eigenen Team.

Eine schon erwähnte Lernform ist der Promtathon, der eine Art Hackathon ist, wobei kleine Gruppen Herausforderungen aus Ihrem Arbeitsalltag mit KI-Tool lösen. Firmen wie die Deutsche Telekom, Continental oder auch SAP nutzen dieses Format bereits.

Bei der Gestaltung solcher praxisorientierten Lernformate sind aus eigener Erfahrung folgende Punkte zu beachten:

  • Nutzung zentraler Kommunikationstools, z.B. digitale Whiteboards
  • Analyse und Nutzung von Herausforderungen aus dem täglichen Arbeitsleben
  • Selbstorganisation fördern und fordern
  • Diversität der Skills in den Lerngruppen
  • Minimaler Input, dafür maximale Praxis 
  • Dokumentation und Reflexion der Ergebnisse und des Lösungswegs

Austausch in Communities wie der SAP Training und Change Community, der Corporate Learning Community oder der benachbarten LernOS Community ist für Learning Experten ein wichtiges Lern- und Experimentierfeld. Im besten Fall entstehen wie hier durch Co-Creation sogar Werkzeuge,  die der AI Adoption weiterhelfen.

Aufgrund der dynamischen Entwicklung im Bereich KI wird das kontinuierliche Lernen neuer KI Anwendungen und Modelle auch über 2025 hinaus sehr relevant sein. Auch hier eigenen sich Methoden aus dem Peer-Learning und dem erfahrungsbasierten Lernen.

Adoption reicht nicht, es benötigt auch Adaption & Transformation

Neben den 4 Dimensionen ist der Unterschied zwischen Adoption, Adaption & Transformation zentral.

Adoption bedeutet die Akzeptanz und eigentliche Nutzung neuer KI-Technologien. Jedoch sollte man nicht nur bestehende Aufgaben schneller mit KI machen.

Adaption geht darüber hinaus: Arbeitsweisen, Aufgaben und Prozesse werden aktiv an die Technologie angepasst. Dies verlangt Veränderungsbereitschaft, Lernen und Experimentieren, um KI sinnvoll zu integrieren.   

Transformation schließlich beschreibt den tiefgreifenden Wandel von Aufgaben, aber auch Geschäftsmodellen, Wertschöpfung und Rollen. KI ermöglicht Neues, zuvor nicht dagewesenes und verändert damit Arbeit, Organisation und Zusammenarbeit.

Abb. 2: Das Adoption, Adaption, Transformation Modell (eigene Darstellung)

Diese 3 Stufen sind zentrale Schritte eines Entwicklungsprozesses. Auf keinen Fall darf man auf der Stufe der reinen Nutzung stehen bleiben, will man das Potential von KI wirklich nutzen. Ähnlich sieht dies auch Josh Bersin (2025) in seinem Beitrag „die vier Stufen der KI Transformation“. Passend dazu fordert Ethan Mollicks (2025) Konzept „Leadership, Lab and Crowd“ für erfolgreiche KI-Transformation, den Gap zwischen Theorie und Praxis durch organisationale Lernprozesse zu überwinden.

Reflektion zur menschzentrierten KI Adoption

Für die Einführung und Nutzung generativer KI ist es wichtig, dass jeder aktiv experimentiert und versucht, KI überall dort einzusetzen, wo es möglich ist. Wie beim Lernen vom Autofahren kann man etwas darüber lesen – aber um es wirklich zu beherrschen und sich auch anzupassen, muss man es erleben und üben.

Organisationen müssen daher nicht nur die Werkzeuge, sondern auch Raum zum Lernen und Experimentieren anbieten. Hier können Communities und Peer-Learning helfen. 

Neben dem Toolset ist es zudem hilfreich, Menschen für die KI-Nutzung zu belohnen und nicht zu bestrafen. Wenn Produktivitätsgewinne erzielt werden, müssen auch die Mitarbeiter davon profitieren bzw. sollten keine Angst vor den Folgen haben. Psychologische Sicherheit ist dabei der Schlüssel zur Bereitschaft, Innovationen zu teilen oder sich überhaupt zu trauen, etwas neues zu versuchen. Daher ist es hilfreich, eine solche Kultur der psychologischen Sicherheit zu fördern, einschließlich des Lernens aus Fehlern und des Vorlebens durch Beispiel. (Ja - Manager reden oft noch zuviel über KI, anstatt KI selbst auch aktiv zu nutzen). 

Ohne den Fokus auf Menschen werden KI-Implementierungen nicht nur weniger erfolgreich sein - sie können sogar schädlich sein. Verhindern wir dies und arbeiten wir gemeinsam an einem menschenzentrierten Einsatz von KI. 

Quellen

Bersin, Josh (2025): The Road To AI-Driven Productivity: Four Stages of Transformation. Abgerufen am 03.09.2025 unter https://joshbersin.com/2024/11/how-to-make-productivity-soar-four-stages-of-ai-transformation/

CLC Promptathon: Blogs & Podcast (2024) + Leitfaden für Promptathons

Jenewein, Thomas (2025): AI Adoption: from technology to successful usage, acceptance to adaption and transformation. SAP Blogs. Abgerufen am 03.09.2025 unter https://community.sap.com/t5/sap-training-and-change-management/ai-adoption-from-technology-to-successful-usage-acceptance-to-adaption-and/ba-p/13922954

Jenewein, Thomas (2024): Generative Künstliche Intelligenz im Corporate Learning: Use Cases, Beispiele und Tips. Abgerufen am 03.09.2025 unter https://community.sap.com/t5/sap-training-and-change-management/generative-k%C3%BCnstliche-intelligenz-im-corporate-learning-use-cases-beispiele/ba-p/13767754

Im EducationNewscast Podcast reflektiere ich zudem regelmäßig Themen rund um KI – neben konkreten Projekterfahrungen stammen hier auch einige meiner Erkenntnisse hier im Blog

LernOS KI Leitfaden (2025) Leitfaden zum Erlernen generativer KI in Lernzirkeln

Mollick, Ethan (2025): Making AI Work: Leadership, Lab, and Crowd. A formula for AI in companies. Abgerufen am 03.09.2025 unter https://www.oneusefulthing.org/p/making-ai-work-leadership-lab-and

Mollick, Ethan (2024): Co-Intelligence: Living and Working with AI. Penguin Random House UK.

Verbindet Euch gerne auch via Linkedln I Mastodon I Bluesky I Podcast

entry.title: Observability for non-SAP Components using SAP Cloud ALM
entry.content:
• Introduction
  • Architecture Overview
  • Configuration Overview
  • Instrument Tomcat with OpenTelemetry
  • Register Service in SAP Cloud ALM
  • Get SAP Cloud ALM API Service Credentials
  • Install and configure the OTel Collector
  • Activate Data Collection in SAP Cloud ALM
  • Check results in Health Monitoring
  • Activate and check results in Real User Monitoring
  • Activate and check results in Integration and Exception Monitoring
  • Key Takeaways
  • Link Collection
  • Glossary

 

Introduction

In today's enterprise environments, organizations increasingly depend on a diverse mix of tools, platforms, and custom applications, both SAP and non-SAP. SAP's core strategic goal is to empower IT teams by simplifying this complexity and seamlessly integrating and monitoring these varied systems and services.

If you’re running non-SAP workloads—like Java applications on Apache Tomcat—but want centralized visibility and operations in SAP Cloud ALM, OpenTelemetry provides a clean path. SAP Cloud ALM can be used as a centralized, unified platform for monitoring, managing, and optimizing all components, including cloud-native services and third-party systems.

In this blog, we'll explore how you can leverage SAP Cloud ALM to monitor non-SAP systems using Inbound raw APIs and OpenTelemetry. As part of this blog we will focus on Health Monitoring, Real User monitoring and Integration and Exception monitoring. More applications can consume external signals, complete list per signal type can be found in link collection at the end.

 

Architecture Overview

The list of key components for monitoring external entities with SAP Cloud ALM using OpenTelemetry includes:

  • OpenTelemetry Java Agent
  • OpenTelemetry Collector
  • SAP Cloud ALM raw inbound APIs

The OpenTelemetry Java Agent is a tool designed to automatically collect telemetry data, such as traces and metrics, from Java applications. It is part of the OpenTelemetry project, which aims to provide a standardized way to gather observability data for applications, making it easier to monitor their performance and troubleshoot issues.

The OpenTelemetry Collector is a component of the OpenTelemetry project that serves as an intermediary for processing, transforming, and exporting telemetry data (traces, metrics, logs) to monitoring and observability backends.

SAP Cloud ALM raw inbound APIs are interfaces that allow external systems and applications to send telemetry data directly into SAP Cloud ALM applications like Health Monitoring, Real User Monitoring or Integration and Exception Monitoring.

In this article we will describe how to configure an external system (Tomcat server) to show metrics, logs and traces in SAP Cloud ALM using all the key components.

The receiving entity in our architecture is a SAP Cloud ALM application depending on the type of signal involved:

  • Real User Monitoring or Synthetic User Monitoring for traces
  • Health Monitoring for metrics
  • Exception Monitoring for logs

 

Configuration Overview

Required configuration steps can be summarized as follows:

  1. Instrument Tomcat with OpenTelemetry
  2. Register Service in SAP Cloud ALM
  3. Get SAP Cloud ALM API Service Credentials
  4. Install and configure the OTel Collector
  5. Activate Data Collection in SAP Cloud ALM

 

Instrument Tomcat with OpenTelemetry

In general, instrumenting an application or service with OpenTelemetry means adding the “sensors” that let you see what the software is doing in production.

Instrumenting a Tomcat server with OpenTelemetry means enabling Tomcat and the web apps it hosts to emit standardized traces, metrics, and logs so you can see request flow, latency, errors, and resource usage.

This is exactly the role of the OpenTelemetry Java Agent which hooks into the JVM at startup and automatically detects common frameworks (JDBC, messaging, etc.) creating spans and metrics with appropriate context propagation. The agent can be setup to send data to a specific backend (like the OTel Collector) via configured exporters. Instrumentation is enabled/controlled by configuration (environment variables, system properties) rather than code.

The opentelemetry-javaagent.jar file must be placed in a directory accessible by the Tomcat server (e.g. $CATALINA_HOME/lib/) and the -javaagent:$CATALINA_HOME/lib/opentelemetry-javaagent.jar option must be added either to CATALINA_OPTS or the setenv.sh file like here:

#https://github.com/open-telemetry/opentelemetry-java-instrumentation/releases
#Previous: 1.33.3
#Current: 2.12.0
#attaches the OpenTelemetry Java agent to Tomcat at startup and turns on Tomcat-specific JMX metric scraping
export CATALINA_OPTS="$CATALINA_OPTS -javaagent:$CATALINA_HOME/lib/opentelemetry-javaagent_2.12.0.jar -Dotel.jmx.target.system=tomcat"

#uses OTLP over gRPC (port 4317) for exporting, more efficient if signals are sent to a Collector
export OTEL_EXPORTER_OTLP_PROTOCOL=grpc
#points all OTLP exports to the OpenTelemetry Collector (or backend) at host demo_otel, port 4317.
export OTEL_EXPORTER_OTLP_ENDPOINT=http://demo_otel:4317

#enable exporting logs, metrics and traces via OTLP
export OTEL_LOGS_EXPORTER=otlp
export OTEL_METRICS_EXPORTER=otlp
export OTEL_TRACES_EXPORTER=otlp

#sets resource attributes added to every signal: service name is Tomcat-Server and a custom tag sap.custom=ALM-Demo.
export OTEL_RESOURCE_ATTRIBUTES=service.name=Tomcat-Server,sap.custom=ALM-Demo

OTEL_EXPORTER_OTLP_PROTOCOL and OTEL_EXPORTER_OTLP_ENDPOINT are used to point where all the telemetry should go while OTEL_*EXPORTER options are used to make sure every signal gets shipped with the proper protocol (on modern agents, traces and metrics default to OTLP anyway, but explicitly enabling logs ensures they’re exported too if log correlation is configured).

OTEL_RESOURCE_ATTRIBUTES is just used to add some identity to the data by adding tags to every trace/metric/log with a service name and a custom attribute.

After restart, servlets, filters, and JSPs, as well as common libraries, will be auto-instrumented, and the server will start sending signals to the OTel host with no code modifications.

 

Register Service in SAP Cloud ALM

To configure non-SAP services, you need to ensure they can send signals to SAP Cloud ALM and that they are represented in the Landscape Management application in SAP Cloud ALM as an unspecific cloud service.

This is a crucial step because the Landscape ID  generated at the end of the process (e684466f-446d-4a53-a899-f0af6d94731e in this example) will be used in the OTel Collector configuration to send the signals to the proper entity in each application.

 

 

Get SAP Cloud ALM API Service Credentials

Any entity sending data to SAP Cloud ALM must be authenticated to be able consume the APIs. The procedure to enable SAP Cloud ALM APIs is described here. The goal is to be able to retrieve service credentials.

In this example service credentials are necessary to authenticate the collector with SAP Cloud ALM API, specifically clientid, clientsecret, and url attributes in the uaa section of the credentials form. This can be retrieved from the BTP Cockpit for the SAP Cloud ALM API service.

 

Install and configure the OTel Collector

As explained before, the OpenTelemetry collector is a proxy that can receive, process, and export telemetry data in various formats (such as Jaeger, Prometheus, and OTLP) and send it to one or more backends, including SAP Cloud ALM.

Collectors can be installed and setup in few minutes; there are essentially two options: use the image and binaries from the github release project (this option will include all the receivers, exporters and extensions) or build and install a custom collector configured using specific receivers, exporters and extensions. The minimal requirement needed to authenticate the collector to the SAP Cloud ALM API is the oauth2clientauthextension. 

Regardless the installation option, setup is done via a configuration file (otel-config.yaml in the example below). 

Using docker, it is quite straightforward to start and test a collector:

docker run -v ./otel-config.yaml:/etc/otelcol-contrib/config.yaml \
-p 127.0.0.1:4317:4317 \
-p 127.0.0.1:55679:55679  \
otel/opentelemetry-collector-contrib

This command runs the OpenTelemetry Collector in a Docker container, using a custom configuration file in the current directory (otel-config.yaml) and exposing two ports (4317 and 55679) for communication with the host.

The collector yaml file includes mainly four sections:

  • Receivers
  • Processors
  • Exporters
  • Services

Below is an example of a configuration file using the service credential attributes—specifically clientid, clientsecret, and url—as explained in the "Get SAP Cloud ALM API Service Credentials" section. These attributes are used for oauth2client authentication within the OpenTelemetry Collector configuration.
When configuring the oauth2client extension, ensure that the token_url parameter is constructed by appending /oauth/token to the provided url value. This step is required for proper authentication against the SAP Cloud ALM API.

 

extensions:

#This enables zPages, a web-based UI for viewing in-process telemetry data.
#It listens on port 55679 and can be accessed via http://<otel-collector-host>:55679/zpages
  zpages:
    endpoint: 0.0.0.0:55679

#This is used to authenticate requests sent by the exporters. 
#In this case the client_id (sb-sapcloudalmapi!b48494|sapcloudalm!b36409) includes a character | which is not supported in the file or string.
#OpenTelemetry typically expects the client_id and client_secret to be provided via a file (e.g., client_id_file) or as a simple string without special characters like |, hence we use files here. 
#Make sure the files are protected and not accessible by unauthorized users.
 
  oauth2client/prod:
    client_id_file: ./client_id_file
    client_secret_file: ./client_secret_file
    token_url: https://calm-acme-demo.authentication.eu10.hana.ondemand.com/oauth/token

#This defines a receiver that listens for telemetry data (metrics, logs, traces) from the otlp/tomcat source.
#It uses the gRPC protocol and listens on port 4317 for incoming data. This is the same port that the Tomcat OpenTelemetry Java agent is configured to send data to.
#Make sure that the port 4317 is open and not blocked by any firewall or network security group.
receivers:
  otlp/tomcat:
    protocols:
      grpc:
        endpoint: 0.0.0.0:4317

#This improves performance by reducing the number of requests and optimizing network usage.
processors:
  batch:

#These define exporters that send telemetry data to external systems.
#There are three exporters, one for each type of telemetry data: metrics, logs, and traces.
#Each exporter is configured to send data to a specific endpoint in the SAP Cloud ALM system
#Each exporter uses the oauth2client/prod extension for authentication.
exporters:
  otlphttp/tomcat_metrics:
    metrics_endpoint: https://eu10.alm.cloud.sap/api/calm-metrics/v1/metrics?serviceId=e684466f-446d-4a53-a899-f0af6d94731e&useCase=hm&dev=false&tag=otelcol_prodemo
    compression: none
    auth:
      authenticator: oauth2client/prod
    headers:
      Content-type: "application/x-protobuf"

  otlphttp/tomcat_logs:
    logs_endpoint: https://eu10.alm.cloud.sap/api/calm-logs/v1/logs?serviceId=e684466f-446d-4a53-a899-f0af6d94731e&useCase=exm&dev=false&tag=otelcol_prodemo
    compression: none
    auth:
      authenticator: oauth2client/prod
    headers:
      Content-type: "application/x-protobuf"

  otlphttp/tomcat_traces:
    traces_endpoint: https://eu10.alm.cloud.sap/api/calm-traces/v1/traces?serviceId=e684466f-446d-4a53-a899-f0af6d94731e&useCase=rum&dev=false&tag=otelcol_prodemo
    compression: none
    auth:
      authenticator: oauth2client/prod
    headers:
      Content-type: "application/x-protobuf"

#The service section ties everything together.
service:

#Uses the oauth2client/prod extension for authentication and enables zPages for monitoring.
  extensions: [zpages,oauth2client/prod]

#Defines how telemetry data flows:
  pipelines:
#Receives metrics, batches them, and sends them to otlphttp/tomcat_metrics.
    metrics/tomcat:
      receivers: [otlp/tomcat]
      processors: [batch]
      exporters: [otlphttp/tomcat_metrics]
#Receives logs, batches them, and sends them to otlphttp/tomcat_logs.
    logs/tomcat:
      receivers: [otlp/tomcat]
      processors: [batch]
      exporters: [otlphttp/tomcat_logs]
#Receives traces, batches them, and sends them to otlphttp/tomcat_traces.
    traces/tomcat:
      receivers: [otlp/tomcat]
      processors: [batch]
      exporters: [otlphttp/tomcat_traces]
Spoiler
You can check the status of the local collector accessing the link http://localhost:55679/debug/servicez. This will show you the enabled extensions and features. 

In short: 

  • Receiver otlp/tomcat collect telemetry data.
  • Processors (like batch) optimize the data before exporting.
  • Exporters, like otlphttp/tomcat_metrics, send the data to external systems (SAP Cloud ALM Health monitoring application)
  • Service defines how everything works together using pipelines like metrics/tomcat.

 

Collector metric data flow

 

Activate Data Collection in SAP Cloud ALM

After restarting the collector, signals will be sent to the SAP Cloud ALM applications. To actually see the data in each application, few additional steps are needed.

 

Check results in Health Monitoring

If everything is set up properly, Health Monitoring will display the metrics list for the custom Tomcat service you created. Simply choose "Unspecific Cloud Service" as the service type in the scope selector

Scope Selector for Unspecific Cloud Services

and confirm that data collection is enabled for the "Tomcat" service in your configuration.

 

Health Monitoring Overview and Service activation

 

To view system details, just click on the Unspecific Cloud Service tile:

 

Monitoring Overview

 

Monitoring System Details

 

Activate and check results in Real User Monitoring

To enable Real User Monitoring for Tomcat, select the unspecific cloud service

 

Real User Monitoring scope selection for Unspecific Cloud Services

 

click the configuration wheel, and activate data collection in Managed Components.

 

Real User Monitoring: Tomcat data collection and Overview

 

Requests traces will then be available in the detailed pages:

       RUM Requests Overview

 

RUM Request Executions

 

Activate and check results in Integration and Exception Monitoring

Error logs will appear on the Exception Monitoring page as soon as data collection is activated, just like Health Monitoring and Real User Monitoring.

 

Integration and Exception Monitoring Overview

  Integration and Exception Monitoring details

 

 

Key Takeaways

  • Unified Monitoring: SAP Cloud ALM enables centralised monitoring and management of both SAP and non-SAP systems, providing a centralized entry point for IT operations.
  • OpenTelemetry Integration: Leveraging the OpenTelemetry Java Agent and Collector allows for seamless collection and forwarding of telemetry data (metrics, logs, traces) from external systems such as Tomcat servers.
  • API-Driven Data Ingestion: SAP Cloud ALM’s raw inbound APIs facilitate direct ingestion of external telemetry data, supporting use cases like Health Monitoring, Real User Monitoring, Exception Monitoring and more.
  • Step-by-Step Configuration: The integration process involves instrumenting the external system, registering it in SAP Cloud ALM, obtaining API credentials, configuring the OpenTelemetry Collector, and activating data collection in the relevant SAP Cloud ALM applications.
  • Security and Authentication: Secure authentication is achieved using service credentials (client ID, client secret, and token URL) when configuring the OpenTelemetry Collector to communicate with SAP Cloud ALM.
  • Operational Visibility: Once configured, IT teams gain real-time visibility into the health, performance, and exceptions of external systems, enhancing proactive management and troubleshooting.
  • Extensibility: The approach is adaptable to a wide range of non-SAP workloads and can be extended to additional applications and signal types as needed.

 

Link Collection

  • RAW inbound APIs
  • Expert Portal
    • Health Monitoring
    • Real User Monitoring
    • Integration and Exception Monitoring 
  • OpenTelemetry
    • Java Agent
    • Java Agent Releases 
    • Collector
    • Custom Collector
    • Collector Contrib Release
    • Collector Oauth Extension

 

Glossary

BTP Cockpit (SAP Business Technology Platform Cockpit): is the web console for administering SAP BTP: manage accounts and regions, assign entitlements, provision services, configure environments and connectivity, handle users/roles and security, and monitor usage and billing.

OTel (OpenTelemetry): open-source observability framework that standardizes collection of telemetry data - traces, metrics, and logs- from applications and services, providing vendor-neutral SDKs, APIs, and agents to export data to backends for monitoring and analysis.

JMX (Java Management Extensions): Java technology for monitoring and managing applications, JVMs, and resources via MBeans, enabling runtime configuration, metrics, and operations through standard APIs and remote connectors (e.g., JMX RMI).

entry.title: Error V/005 – Payment card duplication issue during customer extension to sales area
entry.content:
Hello Experts,

I’m working on a client requirement where a single payment card (credit card) number can be assigned to multiple customers.

To suppress the duplicate check error — “Payment card is already used by other BP” — we deactivated the implementation CVI_CC_CHECK_BP_SIDE from the BAdI BUPA_PCARD_CHECK. After deactivating it, the duplicate card error no longer appears.

However, we are now encountering a new error when extending a customer to a sales area and saving it:

Error: “Customer data were not saved due to error V/005”
Long Text: “Payment card XXXXXXXX is already assigned (V/005)”

Could you please share your thoughts on how we can suppress these errors from the BP/Customer side while allowing multiple customers to use the same payment card?

Thank you,

Gaurav Mishra

entry.title: Re: How to migrate service purchase order data by migrati...
entry.content:
Hello @Lily16 

I believe I Provided the answer you mentioned below. Here is a follow up.

In summary, what you are trying to do is not supported in public cloud. The standard migration object does not support Purchase Orders that reference a Service Order. The migration template as you noticed contains Sales Order, Sales Item and so on, but does not include the Service Document and Service Document item fields. The reason is the clean-core approach used in the public cloud. Service-related Purchase Orders must be created automatically from Service Orders and not migrated or created manually.

What is recommended is for you, is to use scope item 4HH-Service Order Processing with External Procurement. Create the Service Order in the Manage Service Orders App. The system automatically generates a Purchase Requisition and then a Purchase Order linked to the Service Document.

If your legacy Pos are only needed for reporting (a workable fallback), you may load them through Migrate Purchase Orders but leave Service Order reference blank. These Pos will not be functionally linked to Service Orders.

The following references will provide you with more details.

Migration of Purchase Orders, https://api.sap.com/api/API_MATERIAL_DOCUMENT_SRV/overview

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_BUSINESS_BYDESIGN/0635ec3491974ad988be05d6b1dcf734/2da5a553722d1014a062d17a4124c536.html?locale=en-US

Blog: Migration Cockpit- Open Purchase Order confirms, the information you received is right. Here are some more details.

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

PS: Did you contact your system administrator to activate the service order app?

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: SQL anywhere17 ODBC driver
entry.content:
hello,

messed with the same error...

when you do an ldd on the .so file you see that a dependency file is not found.
you fix this by setting an environment variable -> export LD_LIBRARY_PATH=/opt/sqlanywhere17/lib64

just for information: after setting this odbcinst -j doesn't work till the LD_LIBRARY_PATH is set blank (if you trying to test something).

entry.title: SAP Community Voice: Get Ready for SAP TechEd, Certifications and Upcoming Events Around the World!
entry.content:
October is coming to an end, and that means it’s time for another recap of everything that’s been happening across the SAP Community!

Everyone is looking forward to SAP TechEd in Berlin, but the past two weeks have already given us a taste of so many exciting things happening throughout the SAP ecosystem. Did you take part in Devtoberfest? This online event was remarkable and full of insights!

There’s been plenty of on-site action too, from SAP Inside Tracks and Stammtisch meetups bringing members together locally, to the launch of the Argentina location group. We are happy to see our SAP connections grow even further.

Let’s dive in and see what’s new!

Featured blog posts

SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) Planning and Reporting

SAP’s member Tano Breutner shared valuable insights on the importance and limitations of the Version Dimension in SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) Planning. He explains that, although some recommendations suggest simplifying the model by using a single version member and managing versions through a custom public dimension, he prefers to use the version dimension as it was intended. In his blog post, Tano points out that the version dimension has certain restrictions. Therefore, he encourages users to support SAP’s Customer Influence initiatives to help make the version dimension more flexible and public in future updates.

Read the blog post here 

Update for the SAP BTP trial community

Due to an unusually high amount of misuse limiting the availability for all users, the SAP BTP trial product team announced the temporary restriction in the system. SAP´s Carolin Boeke, explained that for the next weeks, the SAP BTP trial will not be able to deliver this experience for new SAP BTP trial accounts, to prioritize security. You will still be able to build applications and preview them, but deployment in the SAP BTP Cloud Foundry runtime will not be possible for the next few weeks. Although, if you have an existing account that was created before October 15th, you are not affected. 

Read the blog post here

How to Launch your Data Science Platform with SAP Business Data Cloud

SAP’s member Joelle Strubel outlines how to activate SAP Datasphere with SAP Databricks within the SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) architecture. She clarifies that SAP Databricks uses its own object store, separate from the BDC Object Store, which will not be activated in this setup to preserve data semantics. This step-by-step guide is very straightforward, and she uploaded images to help you visualize better. Make sure to check it out and try it!

Read the blog post here

SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition: Guide on How to Drive more Business outcomes

If you are looking for a way to get more out of your subscription investment, this recommendation blog post by SAP’s Marco Valencia is a must-read. He goes over some initiatives based on his personal experience, including the use of Release Assessment and Scope Dependency for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, the exploration of the SAP RASD Tool for SAP Business AI (e.g., SAP Joule), the Manage News Fiori application in the My Home page, and much more. Read the full details of each one of his key points and find some valuable insights for your new projects and business rollouts.

Read the blog post here

Community News

Josh “Bluebeard” explain the 9 things you need to know about SAP Community at SAP TechEd in Berlin 

We have been waiting all year and now the SAP TechEd in Berlin is almost here! This conference is not just another tech event, but like Josh Bentley (or “Bluebeard”) described: “It´s where SAP Community comes home!” With that, he prepared a list of the 9 things you should know to have the most out of this experience. His main keynotes are Connect at the Community Clubhouse, Dive into the Developer Garage, Learn from Experts, Explore the Community Theatre, Learning and Certification Opportunities, Step into SAP TechEd Experience Center, Get to Know the SAP Community Platform, Connect with Mentors and Champions and Don´t Miss the Developer Keynote. Please, make sure to read his full blog post here for more details of each one of his recommendations. 

Get Certified at SAP TechEd!

Like we just mentioned on the topic before, one of the main opportunities for our SAP Community members is the chance to learn and get certified. SAP TechEd in Berlin offers a dedicated space to take the certifications on-site. Take a free on-site certification exam for SAP Generative AI Developer and SAP Build Developer in Berlin, Bangalore, or Louisville to validate your skills and stand out with SAP-certified expertise. Find more details and register for the exam here.

Hobbies Series with SAP Champion Sandra Solis 

One of our biggest highlights on the last editions of the Community Voice has been the Hobbies Series blog posts. And this week we are more than happy to share SAP Champion Sandra Solis post about her passion for drawing and painting! Sandra is an ABAP developer from Mexico, and you probably already saw some of her useful tips and insights, but we would like to bring visibility also to her amazing artistic side. She has been using her creativity and techniques with colored pencils, charcoal, watercolor, and even coffee painting for more than 20 years. On her blog post she shared more details on how she started but also some pictures of her work of art. She even painted with coffee portraits of the SAP Developer Advocates. We were completely obsessed with these iconic pieces. Check here and give Sandra some support for her incredible work in the comments.  

New location group: Argentina!

Big news for our SAP community members from South America: we just launched the Argentina group! This is another step on our goal to reach more locations all over the world and bring together SAP experts, students, partners, and every single person that is passionate about SAP topics. The group is run by  @MatiasLemos and @mariano_acevedo, and they are more than excited to create this opportunity to expand the connections around Argentina, bring insights and start local events. If you are a member of this area, make sure to register here, share, and collaborate with your ideas.  

Events

Devtoberfest 2025: It’s a Wrap!

On October 24, last Friday, we had our last session of Devtoberfest 2025. We would like to appreciate all the developers who helped put this event together and each speaker for their collaboration with the SAP Community. But most importantly, we would like to take a moment to say thank you to everyone who attended! In case you missed it and would like to check it out, make sure to visit the Developers YouTube Playlist for a recap. Also, if by any chance you have not registered your participation or have not received your points yet, make sure to check this guide for the SAP Developer Tutorial. If you are waiting for the results for the Grand Prize, the winner will be announced live at SAP TechEd Berlin during the week of November 4th, 2025. Email notifications will also be sent after the event announcement. 

UI5con Bengaluru is Back in 2025

After a hiatus of six years, UI5con Bengaluru is back this year! The event will take place on December 13, 2025, at the SAP Labs India Innovation Park, Bengaluru. Beyond the chance to connect and contribute to the local community, you can also participate by speaking and sharing your expertise. Until October 30th, you can submit your proposal in three different formats: a 20-minute Quickfire Presentation, a 40-minute In-Depth Presentation, or a 60–90-minute Hands-On Workshop. Make sure to read the full details on how to apply here. Don’t miss this opportunity to go beyond networking by bringing your insights to other SAP members!

SAP Webinar Open Source: Model Context Protocol (MCP) Servers

SAP's commitment to open source extends to its SAP Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP), Fiori elements, and UI5, enabling developers to build robust and scalable applications with enhanced user interfaces. Learn how these three MCP servers facilitate SAP BTP development using large language models (LLMs) and discover how they can accelerate your development process. To learn more, join the SAP Webinar on November 19th by registering here. For further details, check out the recent blog post as well.

Recap of SAP community driven events! 

SAP community event organizers have been doing their best this entire year, and we love to see so many of our Location Groups active and meeting in person. Last weekend happened the SAP Inside Track in Fortaleza, Brazil, an entire day of online and on-site sessions, networking, special giveaways, and an outstanding music performance to celebrate the local culture. None of this could have been done without the brilliant work of the event organizers and the SAP Champions Jonys Arcanjo and Manuel Robalinho. To watch the recap of all sessions and more details, please check the blog post here. 

Now jumping to the other side of the world, on October 25 the Sydney Stammtisch was also a successful event! This is the third edition of the local event and had around 38 attendees. Stammtisch is always the perfect small and warm environment to welcome new people. Thank you to the event organizers and everyone that made sure to stop by and collaborate with the community. Check the blog post recap here by Mike Doyle and keep an eye on his posts for the next meetups in Sydney. 

Upcoming SAP Community On-Site Events!  

Only two months until 2026 arrives but let´s not forget that are still many other local events to happen until the end of the year. And it could be the perfect opportunity for you to get together with some members in your area to connect in person and make the best out of 2025! You can view the full list on the Events page using the filters of Label “Physical.” But, to make your life easier we also separated here for the upcoming 4 weeks: 

  • SAP Stammtisch / Meetup Dortmund, October 29, 2025 
  • SAP Meetup Barcelona, October 30th, 2025,  
  • SAP Stammtisch Berlin (Eve of SAP TechEd 2025), November 3, 2025 
  • SAP Inside Track Paraguay – Ciudad del Este, November 8, 2025 
  • SAP Stammtisch / Meetup Düsseldorf, November 13, 2025 
  • SAP Inside Track Barcelona, November 13, 2025 
  • SAP Stammtisch Melbourne, November 16, 2025 
  • SAP Meetup Singapore, November 20, 2025 
  • SAP Stammtisch München, November 20, 2025

entry.title: Re: SAP DRC Belgium PEPPOL foreign Intercompany Invoices...
entry.content:
Hello Felipe,

The scope of the B2B e-invoicing mandate in Belgium, applicable as of January 1st 2026, refers to B2B transactions between VAT-registered enterprises established in Belgium.  This means that non-established entities who are registered for VAT purposes in Belgium will not have to comply with the e-invoicing mandate.

So, an enterprise based in the Netherlands with a foreign Belgian VAT-number doesn't fall under the scope of the current mandate.  There is no legal requirement to generate electronic intercompany invoices from the Dutch enterprise to its Belgian affiliate.

I hope this answers your question.

Best regards,

Linda

entry.title: Production variance settlement to CO-PA (instead of Cost center)
entry.content:
In S4HC Public by standard the production variance settlement (PRD) is posted against a profitability segment (CO-PA), whose profit center corresponds to the one maintained in the material master of the product manufactured. 

In S4HANA on-premise, we could configure the settlement so that a cost center (we called it "technical prices") was the receiver of the production variances (PRD), and when CKMLCP is executed, the PRY postings are made against that cost center, and together with the rest of PRD posting and other ML operations (transaction keys), the balance was 0 at period-end closing. If there was any balance in any material due to non-assigned/distributed price differences, we could easily assess them to CO-PA using allocation cycles. 

However, in S4HC Public, since the production variance (PRD) is posted against a PSG, the remaining amount in the "technical prices" cost center corresponds to that production variances + if there are any non-allocated/distributed balances, so that no automatic CO-PA allocation can be done, forcing the client to do manual posting to CO-PA (substracting manually the production variances amount) and besides we fail to the premise that all cost centers must be cleared out at period-end closing so that FI and CO result is the same.

How are you dealing with this matter in other clients? Can I do some kind of substitution to change PSG to cost center? Could SAP release the custo point to change the settlement as in on-premise? 

Thanks. Regards,

entry.title: URGENT: We need your vote to enable custom sorting (sort variants) in Statements (SAP13) - Critical
entry.content:
SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition colleagues!

We have identified a key limitation in the Create Correspondence application (for the Statement of Accounts Receivable report, SAP13) that directly impacts the efficiency of Accounts Receivable (FI-AR) anywhere in the world.

 

THE CRITICAL ISSUE:

Currently, the Line Item Sorting functionality for the SAP13 report only allows the use of standard variants (P1, P3, P5). This means we cannot sort the Statement of Account by essential fields for collection management and reconciliation, such as:

 

FAEDT (Net Payment Due Date)

ZUONR (Assignment Number)

 

Since sorting by Due Date (FAEDT) is vital for prioritizing collection activities, this limitation forces manual processes and reduces the efficiency of the Accounts Receivable (AR) team.

 

THE PROPOSED SOLUTION (AND WHY IT'S GLOBAL!):

We requested that SAP enable the Sort Variants setting for this report, allowing the use of fields that already exist in the underlying MHND table (such as FAEDT, ZUONR, and BELNR).

By enabling this feature, we will optimize collections management and reconciliation for ALL S/4HANA Cloud customers, increasing AR efficiency and accelerating cash flow.

 

HOW TO SUPPORT (12 company votes needed!):

 

Please visit the Customer Influence link and click VOTE:

 

Request ID: 357735

https://influence.sap.com/sap/ino/#/idea/357735

entry.title: Re: RAP cross-BO - enrich root BO obj. page create w. cross-BO info (readonly)
entry.content:
Hey @KamalDeepPareek - thank you for your insights, that helps! I'm not quite certain about the approach of the additional determination on the projection layer you mentioned, am I missing something (i.e on BO/BDEF level) or are you referring to the virtual element (incl. additional ABAP class here)?

I think creating another projection layer (something also Clément mentioned to me) which restricts the interactions on the BO (i.e. field w. "readonly : update") is a great way to go about this. Your addition to use a virtual element on the projection layer is also a good idea (here, using the ABAP class for the "determination" then). In that scenario I wouldn't even require any readonly annotations as these fields are readonly by default.

Having a determination on BO level like in Cléments case here  would require me to have these fields in the BO/DB Table itself, wouldn't it (at the very least I'd add warnings of missing persistence mapping to the BDEF)? But I think even if not, the downside would be that I'd have to go into the BO layer (BDEF + CDS Views) for adding these fields as compared to using the virtual element approach which I can add in the projection layer.

entry.title: Re: RAP cross-BO - enrich root BO obj. page create w. cross-BO info (readonly)
entry.content:
Hey @junwu, I was able to test this approach. TLDR: Works! 😃

To roughly sum it up one last time:

  • 2 Associations on projection level of the root BO 'Order' (one to the original cross BO projection - unrestricted, one to another projection with restricted field access i.e. "readonly" - this could also just have been a simple CDS view without behavior projection and the 'readonly' part could've been solely done using annotations then)
  • 2 virtual elements (e.g.: IsCrossBOCustomerHidden, IsAssocCustomerHidden - names may vary 🍻) on projection level of the root BO 'Order', implemented in an ABAP class where you read the 'Customer' BO via EML (figure out if you find something where "isDraft" is set) and set the virtual elements to true/false accordingly, which is then picked up by the dynamicaly controlled 'hidden' property of the two facets (each one of them pointing to one of the above mentioned associations) thus enabling or disabling the given facet allowing for more dynamic field control

Thanks again! 🙂

entry.title: Re: CDS view about service order and purchase requisition
entry.content:
Goood day @Lily16 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at these references, they provide more detailed guidance.

Service Order Management

https://api.sap.com/api/API_SERVICE_ORDER_SRV/overview

https://api.sap.com/cdsviews/I_PURCHASEREQUISITIONITEMAPI01

In summary, no, there is no single released CDS view that directly joins Service Order to Purchase Requisition in one dataset. However, you can derive the linkage when you combine the following released CDS views that expose the same keys.

The link between a Service Order and its Purchase Requisition exists in the standard CDS views I_ServiceOrderItem and I_PurchaseRequisitionItemAPI01. You can expose both directions through a Custom CDS View without accessing unreleased tables.

Alternatively, though more technical, if you work through the procurement side, the same link is available in I_PurchaseRequisitionItemAPI01.ServiceOrder and I_PurchaseRequisitionItemAPI01. ServiceOrderItem. This means you can also start from the Purchase Requisition CDS view and join back to the Service Order CDS view instead of the other way around

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Order combination flag ignored in STO delivery creati...
entry.content:
Good day @cvlokven 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at these references, they provide more detailed guidance.

Stock Transport Order (OData V4), Stock Transport Order with Delivery via Shipping

Delivery Split for Outbound Delivery Order, Advanced Shipping and Receiving

To summarise, in public cloud, the Order Combination flag is not evaluated for Stock Transport Orders (STOs). This is intended because multi-STO delivery combination is not supported due to architectural and compliance constraints in the SaaS environment. Each STO acts as distinct controlling document for replenishment delivery creation due to the differences in the delivery creation framework. There is also no BAdI that allows combining deliveries across multiple STOs, that logic is only provided in the CIF-restricted Private Cloud Edition.

It worked in Onpremise or Private Cloud because BAdIs such as, LE_SHIP_DELIVERY_PROC or LE_SHP_SUPRESS_DEL_SPLIT could be used to override delivery split logic, which also included STO deliveries.

In Public Cloud, these implementations are not released due to the clean core principles and restricted ABAP layer.

In your use case, if delivery grouping is a business requirement, I suggest you consider Advanced Shipping & Receiving or TM integration. They are the supported frameworks for consolidation in the public cloud.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: My expert playlist, SAP TechEd, Berlin
entry.content:
Hello, dear influencers, experts, fans, and friends from the SAP Community!

It’s finally that time of the year again: SAP TechEd Season!
This year feels extra special to me—it’s the first SAP TechEd happening in Germany since I moved here, and I couldn’t be more excited.

When it comes to building my personal TechEd agenda, it has never been both so easy and so difficult at the same time.

Why difficult?
Because my curiosity is endless. Over my (long) SAP career, I’ve worked across many areas: from writing ABAP code to designing modern user interfaces, from integration to solution and enterprise architecture—where technology truly meets business. I love exploring how technology and business merge, so naturally, I’d like to attend almost every session across the board.

Why easy?
Because priorities are clear this year: AI.
My laser focus will be on everything around custom AI scenarios—how we as engineers can build AI extensions, create Joule AI agents, and leverage the SAP AI Foundation. I believe many of the new challenges (and opportunities!) will emerge here, and I can’t wait to discover how SAP’s newest innovations will empower us.

That said, I’ve shortlisted around 30 sessions I’d love to attend. Realistically, some I’ll have to catch later via SAP TechEd Virtual—but here are my Top 3 “must-watch” sessions:

🚀My Top 3 SAP TechEd 2025 Sessions

  • CT1245 | Hugging Face Transformers in AI Foundation
    I’m learning Hugging Face models, so I’m curious to see how they work within the SAP AI Foundation. This feels like a new superpower for building advanced AI scenarios.

  • AI160 | Build your own AI agent–based solution with the generative AI hub
    Agents are another game-changing technology. Spending two hours diving deep into building custom AI agents to extend SAP products sounds like time very well invested.

  • PAR102 | From MCP to Joule: Unlocking SAP data and AI innovation with Microsoft
    I’ve been exploring how SAP AI Foundation can be integrated with cloud providers beyond the Generative AI Hub. This session will be a great opportunity to hear directly from Microsoft experts on their approach.

  • Bonus: AI101 | Optimize prompts and explore models with the generative AI hub
    Prompt engineering is one of the core skills for creating effective custom AI solutions. This session promises plenty of practical insights to sharpen that skill.

Of course, I wish I could attend everything—but thankfully, many sessions will be available later via SAP TechEd Virtual.

In addition to the AI-focused ones, I’ll also keep a close eye on all sessions related to Joule in the context of ABAP and CAP development—because at the end of the day, AI custom scenarios often start right there (with a little help from Python 😉).

🙌Final Thoughts

To all my fellow SAP Community colleagues:
I wish you an inspiring and knowledge-packed SAP TechEd season. May your curiosity be fueled and your learning appetite at least partly satisfied.

Let’s keep in touch and exchange our learnings in the weeks to come.

All the best,
Douglas

entry.title: Alternative to ECC Cost Planning Transactions (KP06, KP26, KSPI, KSII) in S/4HANA Public Cloud
entry.content:
We are migrating from SAP ECC to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition.

In ECC, we use the following transactions for cost rate calculation:
- KP06: Cost input
- KP26: Quantity input
- KSPI: Unit price calculation
- KSII

We understand that in S/4HANA Public Cloud, the recommended apps are:
- F3162: Manage Cost Rates - Plan
- F3422: Manage Cost Rates - Actual

Questions:
1. Can we still use KP06, KP26, KSPI, KSII transactions in S/4HANA Public Cloud?
2. What functionalities are NOT available with F3162 and F3422 compared to the ECC transactions?
3. Our current process calculates the following standard rates using KP06/KP26/KSPI:
- Standard labor rate
- Standard factory overhead rate
- Standard subcontracting rate
- Standard product overhead rate
- Post-process common overhead rate

Can we achieve the same calculations using F3162/F3422 in S/4HANA Public Cloud?

entry.title: Automatic GL Account Substitution Based on Cost Center and GL Account in S/4HANA Public Cloud
entry.content:
We are migrating from SAP ECC to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition.

Current ECC Process:
When posting costs to specific Cost Centers and GL Accounts, the system automatically converts and posts to designated GL accounts based on a conversion table.

Business Rules:
1. If Cost Center = R&D Department → automatically post to "Research & Development Expenses" GL account
2. If Cost Center = SGA AND GL Account = 9XX (SGA accounts) → automatically post to "Selling, General & Administrative Expenses (for P&L display)" GL account

Conversion happens in real-time during posting using a custom conversion table (Cost Center + GL Account → Target GL Account).

Questions:
1. Is this type of automatic GL account substitution possible in S/4HANA Public Cloud?
2. If yes, which app or scope item should we use?
3. What is the recommended approach for this requirement in S/4HANA Public Cloud?

entry.title: Best practice for changing the default currency of analytical Fiori Tiles in S/4HANA Public Cloud
entry.content:
Dear Ladies and Gentlemen,

I found an read some SAP notes for my task of changing the default currency of analytical Fiori Tiles in S/4HANA Public Cloud, but I am not really sure, what is the best practice and the easyest way to do this.

The user profile settings for language and the default values > General > Display Currency obviously have no effect on the analytical tiles for example in the space "Accounts receivable" > Analytics (there was also a note that this just works for some tiles)

Also there does not seem to be another globel setting for the S/4HANA tenants to change the standard currency for all tiles from USD to EUR as far as I see?

So the only way really seems to be to user the "Manage KPIs and Reports" app auf S/4HANA Public Cloud and change the default currency the in the settings of each indivdual KPI (for eacht tile) and then transport this?

And probably now in S/4HANA Public Cloud I can do this directly in the KPIs provided by SAP without the need to copy each tile and KPI and create custom versions for currency = EUR for all those tiles (as it was proposed in earlier S/4HANA on premise versions)? And those settings will not be overwritten with the next S/4HANA cloud release?

Thanks a lot and kind regards


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Best practice for changing the default currency of an...
entry.content:
Dear Sender,

Hope you are doing well!

Since the behind technology of apps uses are different, the way to change the default currency is different.

Basically, for SAP delivered analytical tiles:

Steps to change the default currency in a Story (eg.URL: https://fioriappslibrary.hana.ondemand.com/sap/fix/externalViewer/#/detail/Apps('F4401')/S33 - Application Type: Analytical, BW Query used (SAP Fiori: SAP Analytics Cloud story)).

  • The standard application supports default values. To check for the same, > Go to Manage KPIs and Reports app > stories > Select Aging Analysis > Applications tab > Click on the tile > Default values is set. For more information, please refer to Maintaining Your Default User Values | SAP Help Portal .
  • If the application supports Variants, you can create a public and default variant. (Refer to 3047239 - How to change the displayed currency in Aging Report for Accounts Payable App - SAP for Me ). 

    • The user has to do a one-time activity:

      1. Load the application.
      2. Click on the variants (down arrow).
      3. Click on "Manage".
      4. Select the new currency variant as "favorite" (star icon) and set it as default.
      5. After reloading, the new default variant will be available for the end user.

      (Data Analyzer and Story Analysis | SAP Help Portal > Features: Manage Variants).

        
      
  • It is possible to make a copy of the Story using the Manage KPIs and Reports app > Stories tab > Select "Aging Report for Accounts Payable" > Click on Copy.

 

Steps to change the default currency in a Report (eg.URL: https://fioriappslibrary.hana.ondemand.com/sap/fix/externalViewer/#/detail/Apps('F1733')/S33 - Application Type: Analytical (SAP Fiori: SAP Smart Business generic drill down app)).

  • The standard application supports default values. This can be checked in Manage KPIs and Reports app > Reports > Select Aging Analysis > Applications tab > Click on the tile > Default values is set. For more information, please refer to Maintaining Your Default User Values | SAP Help Portal .
  • It is possible to change the default value by editing the KPI. This can be done in Manage KPIs and Reports app > Reports > Select Aging Analysis > Click on KPI Source "Payable Amount" > Details > Click on Edit > Change the default value.
  • It is possible to make a copy of the Group/KPI/Report by using the Copy functionality. This can be done in Manage KPIs and Reports app > KPI > Groups tab > Select Aging Analysis > Click on Copy.

 

Your settings can be transported to your latter systems and the settings will not be overwritten with the next S/4HANA Pubic Cloud release.

Hope this clarified to you and thanks for your understanding.

Thanks and Best Regards,
Bell
